Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of Practical Microgrid Stability in the Presence of Random Events

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Analysis of Practical Microgrid Stability in the Presence of Random Events

Microgrids are power distribution systems that are small where total generation capacity is similar to the total demand. Examples may be found in isolated villages, military bases that may or may not be connected to the surrounding power grid, and vehicles ranging from automobiles to satellites to ships. DC microgrids have also been proposed for residential applications, where a single house would be a complete system, and for telecommunications power systems. Microgrids are an enabling technology for widespread deployment of renewable energy, such as solar and wind systems. This project will apply emerging control theory concepts to microgrid stability analysis. Previous researchers have usually assumed that all loads and sources have some ability to be controlled, but in practical systems, most loads change randomly, and renewable resources are subject to weather variations. The random events could cause the microgrid to become unstable and shut down. Microgrids are essential to the expansion of renewable energy due to the distributed nature of renewable energy generation, and the improved stability analysis from this project is needed to give system operators confidence in their proper operation.

The objective of this project is to analyze ac and dc microgrids using advanced techniques that apply to generic impulsive Markov jump linear systems. A Markov jump linear system (MJLS) is a system that jumps instantaneously among a set of linear dynamical systems according to a Markov process. More generically, the transitions in the discrete state could be accompanied by impulses in the continuous-time states, forming an impulsive MJLS. This is a good description for the small-signal characteristics of a microgrid. Unfortunately, generic stability results for an impulsive MJLS are few. In this project, stability results for the subset of impulsive MJLS that appropriately describes microgrids will be derived. Suitable models for both ac and dc microgrids will be derived and analyzed. The results will be parameterized by controller gains and other characteristics that are within the purview of the system designer, so that stability may be guaranteed by design. Both the discrete state, which evolves randomly, and the continuous state, which is deterministic, will be considered simultaneously. The approach will be validated with simulations and experiments. Two example microgrids, one ac and one dc, will be studied to demonstrate the ability to compose an appropriate nonlinear model, to convert it to a set of small-signal models, and to map it into the impulsive MJLS framework. The proposed impulsive MJLS study will be applicable to other dynamical systems, such as networked control systems, that fit a similar framework. Similarly, demonstrating the application of impulsive MJLS methods to microgrids may stimulate research within the power community on other applications that fit a similar structure, such as the load on a voltage regulator module (VRM).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microgrids are power distribution systems that are “small”: total generation capacity is similar to the total demand.  Examples may be found in isolated villages, military bases that may or may not be connected to the surrounding power grid, and vehicles ranging from automobiles to satellites to ships.  DC microgrids have also been proposed for residential applications, where a single house would be a complete system, and for telecommunications power systems.  Microgrids are an enabling technology for widespread deployment of renewable energy, such as solar and wind systems.  This project will apply emerging control theory concepts to microgrid stability analysis.  Previous researchers have usually assumed that all loads and sources have some ability to be controlled, but in practical systems, most loads change randomly, and renewable resources are subject to weather variations.  The random events could cause the microgrid to become unstable and shut down.  Microgrids are essential to the expansion of renewable energy due to the distributed nature of renewable energy generation, and the improved stability analysis from this project is needed to give system operators confidence in their proper operation.

In this project, models were derived for a variety of elements in typical ac and dc microgrids. These models provide an appropriate level of detail for system analysis and design. Further analysis was performed using two frameworks to model the randomness in a real system: hidden Markov models and stochastic hybrid systems. The most extensive results were achieved with a combination of the two frameworks, which created an impulsive Markov jump linear system (impulsive MJLS). This framework enables system designers to manage the complexity of a microgrid while analyzing its behavior. Also, there are many other systems that can be modeled as impulsive MJLS’s that also benefit from the new approach.

The intellectual merit of this project’s outcomes includes new models of grid-tied inverters and dual-active-bridge dc-dc converters; a new phase-locked loop (PLL) appropriate for microgrids; innovative load models appropriate for both microgrid modeling and non-intrusive load monitoring; and stochastic frameworks for analyzing the stability and performance of a microgrid or similar system. The new models provide adequate detail for analyzing a microgrid but are simpler, and therefore more computationally efficient, than previous models. The new PLL has much better performance than previous approaches when the grid voltage is distorted or the frequency changes rapidly, as would be expected in a microgrid. The load models and stochastic frameworks enable the analysis of real microgrids that encounter many random events, whether due to loads varying or renewable energy sources varying. Furthermore, the impulsive MJLS framework is adaptable to many other systems.

The broader impacts of this project’s outcomes include the ability to design more robust microgrids and power conversion systems, as well as other nonlinear systems that are subject to random events. The electric power industry is very conservative for good reason: customers expect reliable power delivery. This project’s results provide tools for power engineers to analyze innovative power delivery approaches that are required for expanding renewable energy. In addition, the stochastic framework has been shown to improve the efficiency of a power converter by adjusting the gains to keep the converter in a high-efficiency regime during transients. It is expected that other applications will emerge that take advantage of the new framework and improve efficiency, performance, and robustness of power conversion systems. Also, the project supported a diverse team of graduate and undergraduate students.
